data.name: lbl_Bagasse
data.value:
BAGASSE
  • Bagasse is the fibrous matter that remains after sugarcane is crushed to extract the juice. It is currently used as a bio-fuel and in the manufacture of pulp and paper products and building materials.
  • For each 10 tons of sugarcane crushed, a sugar factory produces nearly 3 tons of wet bagasse. Since bagasse is a by-product of the cane sugar industry, the quantity of production in each country is in line with the quantity of sugarcane crushed.
  • The high moisture content of bagasse, typically 40 to 50%, is detrimental to its use as a fuel. In general, bagasse is stored prior to further processing. For electricity production, it is stored under moist conditions, and the mild exothermic reaction that results from the degradation of residual sugars dries the bagasse pile slightly. For paper and pulp production, it is normally stored wet in order to assist in removal of the short pith fibres, which impede the papermaking process, as well as to remove any remaining sugar.
  • Bagasse is often used as a primary fuel source for sugar mills. When burned in quantity, it produces sufficient heat energy to supply all the needs of a typical sugar mill, with energy to spare.

data.name: lbl_BioEarth
data.value:
Bio Earth
    Composting is a biological oxidation process by which a mixed microbial population in warm, moist, aerobic environment decomposes organic material. During the process, degradable organic substrate undergoes chemical and physical transformation to give a stable humified product. The product is of value in agriculture both as an organic fertilizer and as soil improver.
    Nutrients Bio Earth
    Nitrogen - N 2.0 - 2.5 %
    Phosphorus – P 1.8 - 2.2 %
    Potassium - K 3.0 - 4.0 %
    BENEFITS:
    The importance of recycling organic wastes is being recognized. Bio Earth energizes the micro organism in the soil by providing early nitrogen, enhancing nutrient availability, increasing water retention, and providing colloidal nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, calcium, sulfur and micronutrients.

data.name: lbl_Cog
data.value:
COGENERATION
  • Power produced by using bagasse as fuel during the crushing season and from saved bagasse or other bio-mass during off season
  • Power from renewable sources
  • Less pollution as compared to other thermal power projects
  • Low gestation period
  • The sugar plants are in rural areas and hence the power produced by them will help in the electrification of these areas.
  • Direct participation of grower members in power sector
  • Additional income can be availed by selling surplus power to State Electricity Board or third party
  • Provides motivation for saving of bagasse as it is a valuable by-product and source of additional income as any surplus can be sold to cogen plants
  • Higher achievement in efficiency and atomization in sugar factory
Details of Co-generation Projects in the State

data.name: lbl_DisclaimerContent
data.value:
Hyperlinking Policy

Links to External Websites/Portals
At many places in this portal, you shall find links to other websites/portals created and maintained by other Government, non-Government / private organizations. These links have been placed for your convenience. When you select a link you are navigated to that website. Once on that website, you are subject to the privacy and security policies of the owners / sponsors of the website. Sugar Commissionerate of Maharashtra is not responsible for the contents and reliability of the linked websites and does not necessarily endorse the views expressed in them. Mere presence of the link or its listing on this portal should not be assumed as endorsement of any kind.

Links to the Sugar Commissionerate of Maharashtra Website by Other Websites/Portals
We do not object you for linking directly to the information that is hosted on our site and no prior permission is required for the same.We do not permit our pages to be loaded into frames on your site. Our Department's pages must load into a newly opened browser window of the user.

Privacy Policy

As a general rule, this portal does not automatically capture any specific personal information from you, (like name, phone number or e-mail address), that allows us to identify you individually. This portal records your visit and logs the following information for statistical purposes, such as Internet Protocol (IP) addresses, domain name, browser type, operating system, the date and time of the visit and the pages visited. We make no attempt to link these addresses with the identity of individuals visiting our site unless an attempt to damage the site has been detected We will not identify users or their browsing activities, except when a law enforcement agency may exercise a warrant to inspect the service provider's logs. DISTILLERY
  • During cane crushing around 4% molasses is obtained as by-product which is further utilized for making alcohol. Alcohol is further used for making Extra Neutral Alcohol and Ethanol.
  • From one MT of molasses, 270 ltrs of alcohol can be produced
  • Average spentwash generated from distillery is 10 litre/one litre of alcohol
  • Through Effluent Treatment Plant, biogas is produced which can be used for boiler and thus in turn save bagasse. Biogas can be used in IC engine for power generation.
  • Bio-composting fertilzer
Details of Distillery Projects In The State

  • Central Government has permitted 5% blending of unhydrous ethanol into petrol .
  • 5% blending of ethanol in diesel is under study
  • Ethanol (99.6% v/v) is produced from dehydration of alcohol (94% v/v)
  • Eco friendly fuel hence reduction in pollution
  • Anti knocking agent, hence engine runs smoothly
  • Oxygenating agent
  • Attractive price hence additional rise in cane price to cane growers

data.name: lbl_FAQDetail
data.value:
Audit Section

  • What is a system adopted for the audit of co-op. sugar factory.
    Ans. The Registrar shall audit , or cause to be audited at least once in each co-operative year,by a person authorised by him by general or special order in writing in this behalf the accounts of every co-op. sugar factory which has been given financial assistance, including gurantee by the State Government, as per the provisions u/s 81 of MCS Act 1960.
  • What are the various types of financial audit ?
    Ans. Various types of audit of co-op. sugar factories as per the provisions of MCS Act 1960 are as under.
    1. Annual financial audit.
    2. Audit by Flying Squade.
    3. Test Audit.
    4. Re-Audit as per the orders of Registrar.
  • What is audit rectificatioin ?
    Ans. If the result of the audit held u/s 81 of MCS Act 1960, discloses any defects in the working of a society the society shall within three months from the date of audit report,explain to the Registrar steps to rectify the defects by submitting a rectification report.
  • Whether Energy audit and Cost audit are made compulsory to the co-op. sugar factories?
    Ans. Cost audit & Energy audit for all co-operative sugar factories have been made mandatory vides order no.SGY2011/C.R.359/14-S dated8th December 2011 issued by Government of Maharashtra.
  • What mechanisum is available with commissioner of sugar for the audit of the co-op. sugar factory. ?
    Ans. An officer in the cader of Joint Registrar (Audit) helps to the Commissioner of Sugar in the day today working related to audit of co-op. sugar factory. 35 Special Auditor, co-op. societies ,(Sugar) with their staff helps the Commissionerate of Sugar for the annual financial audit of the co-op. sugar facatories.

Administration Section

SECTION - A. GENERAL QUESTIONS
  • What is a Co-operative Sugar Factory?
    Ans. It is, “a society, the object of which is to provide cane crushing facilities to its members and to provide its members common amenities and services”
    e.g. - supply of sugarcane seed of high yield varieties, supply of fertilizers/pesticides, guidance/training for high yield of sugarcane, and other facilities for the betterment of the members as well their family members.
  • How is a Co-operative Sugar Factory formed?
    Ans. It may be formed by submitting an Application for Registration (in the prescribed form) to the Registering Authority, along with some prescribed documents and payment of Registration Fee.
    On registration it becomes a body corporate, with perpetual succession and common seal, and with power to acquire, hold and dispose of the property, to enter into contracts and other legal proceedings and to do all such things as are necessary for the purpose for which it is constituted.
    In other words, it gets birth on its registration and the Certificate of Registration is its Certificate of Birth. Government of Maharashtra decided to stop the new registrations of co-operative sugar factories vide its letter s.sa.ka.1002/11254/pr.kr.258/13-C dated 23/01/2003.
  • Who can submit the Application for Registration?
    Ans. The Application is required to be signed by at least ten persons (each of such person belonging to a different family), who are qualified to be Members under the Act, and who reside in the area of operation of the Society. Any one among them may be elected to take the lead (he is called the Chief Promoter, and other signatories are called Promoters) and submit the Application
  • Who are the persons qualified/eligible to be Members?
    Ans. (1) An individual who is competent to contract under the Indian Contract Act, 1872;and who are cane producers / non producers.
    (2) A society registered, or deemed to be registered under the Co-operative Societies Act;
    (3) The State Government or the Central Government;
  • What are the Conditions for Membership?
    Ans. The Application for Membership should be supported by (i) payment of value of prescribed number of shares, (ii) payment of prescribed Entrance Fee, and (iii) certain prescribed documents.
    Once the co-operative sugar factory is registered, shares as prescribed are allotted to Members and each Member is issued with a Share Certificate for the number of shares held by the Member.
  • What are the Conditions for Membership?
    Ans. The Application for Membership should be supported by (i) payment of value of prescribed number of shares, (ii) payment of prescribed Entrance Fee, and (iii) certain prescribed documents.
    Once the co-operative sugar factory is registered, shares as prescribed are allotted to Members and each Member is issued with a Share Certificate for the number of shares held by the Member.
  • What are Byelaws and Model Byelaws?
    Ans. Byelaws are regulations governing the internal management of a Society. Model Byelaws are the ones approved by the Registering Authority and containing almost all conceivable situations affecting the governance of a Society.
  • Is it compulsory for every Society to adopt the New Model Byelaws?
    Ans. No. Byelaws, essentially, are regulations governing the internal management of a society. Adopting Model Byelaws is definitely in the interest of societies, the primary reason being their uniformity and versatility. However, Byelaws do not have statutory (legal) force. It is for every society to decide as to what is in its interest. Though Registrar or State Government can issue direction in public interest, they cannot direct or force to amend the already registered Byelaws. Each society has a right to have its own Byelaws, provided they are in accordance with the Act, the Rules and in the public interest. Hence, it is not compulsory to adopt New Model Byelaws.
  • When does a Co-operative Sugar Factory cease to exist?
    Ans. Certificate of Registration cancelled by the Registrar.
    This normally takes place when (1) the assets and liabilities of the Co-operative Sugar Factory are transferred to another Society; (2) the Co-operative Sugar Factory amalgamates with another Society; (3) the Co-operative Sugar Factory divides itself into two or more Societies; (4) the Co-operative Sugar Factory is wound up; (5) the Co-operative Sugar Factory is deregistered by the Registrar.
  • What is a role of Sugar Commissioner in the working of private sugar factories?
    Ans. Commissioner of Sugar, M.S.Pune has a following role in the working of private sugar factory.
    1. To issue aerial distance certificate to the private sugar factory before its registration.
    2. To provide crushing licence every year for the crushing of sugarcane available with the private sugar factories after completion of required procedure.
    3. To ensure whether a private sugar factory has paid a FRP (Fair and Remunerative Price) fixed by the central government to the sugar cane suppliers within 14 days from the supply of sugarcane to the sugar factory.
  • What powers are conferred on Commissioner of Sugar in the execution of provisions of Sugarcane Control Order 1966 as a cane commissioner?
    Ans. Commissioner of Sugar has conferred following power as cane commissioner vide Sugarcane Control Order 1966.
    1. To provide aerial distance certificate before registration of a co-op. /private sugar factory.
    2. To ensure whether a co-operative/ private sugar factory has paid a FRP (Fair and Remunerative Price) fixed by the central government to the sugar cane suppliers within 14 days from the supply of sugarcane to the sugar factory.
    3. If a co-operative/ private sugar factory has paid a FRP (Fair and Remunerative Price) fixed by the central government to the sugar cane suppliers within 14 days , R.R.C.(Revenue Recovery Certificate) can be issued after a notice for hearing to the concerned issued for the recovery of cane price and the interest due to the sugar cane supplier.
SECTION – B. MEMBERS
  • What are the Classes of Membership?
    Ans. The Membership consists of (i) Producer Members, (ii) Non-Producer member(iii)Co-operative Society (iv) Nominal Members.(v)State Government.
  • What is the difference between Classes of Members?
    Ans. A Producer Member, Non-Producer member, an Co-operative Society, a Nominal Member and State Government may be differentiated as under:
    Producer Member means a person joining in an application for the registration of a co-operative society, which is subsequently registered, or a person duly admitted to membership of a society after registration, and who is engaged in the production of sugarcane.
    Non-Producer Member means a person joining in an application for the registration of a co-operative society, which is subsequently registered, or a person duly admitted to membership of a society after registration, and who is not engaged in the production of sugarcane.
    Co-operative Society means a society registered and governed as per the provisions of Maharashtra co-operative Societies Act, 1960 & Rules 1961.
    Nominal Member means a person admitted to membership as such after registration in accordance with the Byelaws and who is not engaged in the production of sugarcane. State Government means Government of Maharashtra.
  • Do Members have the right inspect records/get copies of documents?
    Ans. Yes, a Member may inspect free of cost books, registers, documents etc as provided in Section 32(1) of the Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act, 1960 and get copies of the documents as provided under Section 32(2) of the Act, on payment of the fees prescribed under rule 27 and 30 of Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Rules 1961.
  • What is Nomination and how is it made?
    Ans. Nomination means appointing a person in one’s place. It is a process by which a Member of a Society intends to transmit his rights of membership to a person or persons of his choice.
    In other words, it is a facility available to a Member to make his intention known to the Society as to how his Shares of a Co-operative Sugar Factory should be transferred after his death.
    Though there is a prescribed form, and it is advantageous to use it, a nomination in any other form is still valid if it is in agreement with Rule 25. A valid nomination should (1) be in writing, (2) contain particulars of the name/s of nominee/s, (3) specify the percentage of share of each nominee (with the total being 100%), (4) be signed by the Member, (5) be attested by two Witnesses. The acknowledgement of the nomination by the Secretary shall be deemed to be the acceptance of nomination. Nomination ensures easy and hassle-free transfer of Flat in the name/s of nominee/s. Nomination may be revoked or varied by any other nomination.
  • How can a Member effectively control the Management of a Society?
    Ans. Members should get a good knowledge of the Byelaws; peruse each notice or communication received/displayed; question doubts; suggest remedies; attend General Body Meetings; inspect records; verify vouchers; and do everything that helps to make the Society a better place to live in. If not satisfied, they may approach the relevant authorities specified under Act and Rules.
  • How to bridle a despotic or hostile MC?
    Ans. Section 72 of the Act declares the General Body of the Society as the final authority. However, instances are aplenty where the Members in the Committee of Management run the Society as their fiefdom. They do not respond to Members’ genuine needs; do not allow Members to inspect records, vouchers etc; do not hold General Meetings, not even Elections to the Managing Committees in time; and the like. When a Managing Committee, elected by the Members to perform duties in accordance with the provisions of the Act, the Rules and the Byelaws of the Society, turns despotic or hostile, Members feel the pinch for not being able to bring down the MC.
    In such a situation, the Member/s may approach the Registrar, who may, depending on the gravity of the issue involved, intervene to restore propriety in the affairs of the Society.
    The Registrar has power not only to enforce performance of obligations but also to remove an erring Managing Committee. (Note: See a related question ‘What if the Election is not held before expiry of the term of the MC?’ under Section C: Managing Committees).
  • When can a Member be expelled from the Membership of the Society?
    Ans. A Member may be expelled from the membership of the Society, if such a Member:
    (1) has persistently failed to Supply the sugarcane produced by him for the purpose of crushing or charges due to the Society;
    (2) has wilfully deceived the Society by giving false information;
    (3) has been in the habit of committing breaches of any of the provisions of the Byelaws of the Society, which, in the opinion of the Committee are of serious nature;
    (4) has furnished false information or omitted to furnish the material information to the Registering Authority at the time of registration of the Society. (Note: ‘What is the procedure for expulsion of a Member?’ and ‘Can an expelled Member be readmitted to the Society?’ are answered under Section C: Managing Committees).
  • When does a person cease to be a Member?
    Ans. A person ceases to be a Member of a Society on his (1) resignation; (2) transfer of shares (3) death; (4) expulsion; (5) stopped supply of sugarcane for crushing for contenious 03 years to the society;
SECTION – C. MANAGING COMMITTEES
  • What are the general functions of a Managing Committee?
    Ans. Some of the important functions of a good Managing Committee include – democratic governance; maintaining Society’s property in good & financialy viable conditions; holding regular and timely Meetings (Committee/General); prudence in incurring expenditure; keeping books of accounts, vouchers, records etc transparent and up-to-date; allowing and encouraging Members inspection of records; timely action against defaulters in regular sugarcane supply; holding election to the Managing Committee before the expiry of its term and the like.
  • What is a Provisional Managing Committee and its period of office?
    Ans. Once a Society is registered, a meeting called the First General Meeting of the Promoters* who have signed the Application for Registration of the Society is required to be held within three months of the registration of the Society.
    The Promoter-Members present in that Meeting constitute a “Nominated” or “Provisional Managing Committee” from amongst themselves to manage the Society, till an election is held. The period of office of the PMC is one year from the date of First General Meeting or till the election is held, whichever is earlier. The PMC should hold the election before the expiry of its term. (*Members are called Promoters before the registration of the Society).
  • What is the period of office of an elected Managing Committee (MC)?
    Ans. Five years under the existing bye-laws applicable to the co-operative sugar factories. It is the duty of every Managing Committee to hold the elections before the expiry of its term.
  • What are the disqualifications for Membership of the MC?
    Ans. A Member who (i) is a defaulter; (ii) has not completed two years of his enrolment as a Member as on the last date of nomination (for election); (iii) has more than two children; (iv) has incurred any disqualifications under the Act, the Rules and the Byelaws is not eligible for being appointed, nominated, elected, co-opted or for being a member of a Managing Committee.
  • What are the kinds of General Meetings (GM)?
    Ans. There are three kinds of General Meetings (1) First General Meeting, (2) Annual General Meeting, and (3) Special General Meeting.
    First General Meeting is held only once in the lifetime of a Society. It is the Meeting of the Promoters* who have signed the Application for Registration of the Society, and required to be held within three months of the date of Registration.
    Annual General Meeting is held annually on or before 14 th August of the next financial year as per the provisions of the Act. A Special General Meeting may be held as per the provisions of section 76 of MCS Act 1960, as and when need arises .
  • What is the period of Notice for General Meetings?
    Ans. There are three kinds of General Meetings (1) First General Meeting, (2) Annual GeneraThe period of Notice for the First and Annual General Meeting (AGM) is “fourteen clear days”, and for the Special General Meeting (SGM) it is “five clear days”.
    It means the number of calendar days intervening between the day of posting/giving the Notice and the day of the Meeting. For example if an AGM/SGM is to be held on 25th of the month, the Notice should be posted/given by or before 10th /19th of that month. However, in case of an emergency, the SGM may be called even at a shorter Notice.
  • When should AGM be called and what if there be failure?
    Ans. The Annual General Meeting (AGM) of every co-operative sugar factory should be held on or before 14th August each year. If, for any reason, this schedule is not possible to be adhered to, the MC should sufficiently in advance apply to the State Government as per the provisions of section 75 of MCS Act 1960, requesting extension of time.
    The State Government may grant extension till the requested time period, or reject the request. If default is made in calling a General Meeting within the period (that is if it is not held by 14th August or within the extended period permitted by the State Government or extension of time is not sought from the State Government, or the request for extension is rejected by the State Government) the Registrar may by order declare any Officer or Member of the Committee whose duty it was to call such a Meeting disqualified for being elected and for being any Officer or Member of the Committee for such period not exceeding three years and, if the Officer is a servant of the Society, impose a penalty on him to pay an amount not exceeding one hundred rupees.
  • When should SGM be called and what if there be failure?
    Ans. A Special General Meeting (SGM) may be called (1) by the Chairman*; (2) by a majority of the Committee*; (3) on a requisition in writing of one-fifth of the Members**; (4) at the instance of the Registrar. (*any time; **must be called within one month).
    The meeting so convened should transact only that business which is mentioned in the Notice of the Meeting. Where any Officer or a Member of the Committee, whose duty it was to call such Meeting, without reasonable cause fails to call such Meeting, the Registrar may by order declare such Officer or Member disqualified for being a Member of the Committee for such period not exceeding three years, and if the Officer is a servant of the Society, he may impose on him a penalty not exceeding one hundred rupees.
  • What is the quorum for a GM and what if there is no quorum?
    Ans. The quorum for every General Body Meeting (GM) is 1/10 th of the total number of Members of the Society. If within half an hour after the time fixed for the Meeting there is no quorum, the Meeting, if convened upon the requisition of the Members, should be dissolved.
    In any other case, the Meeting should be adjourned to a later hour on the same day and at the same place, as may have been specified in the Notice, or to a subsequent date not earlier than seven days and not later than thirty days, and at such adjourned GM, the business on the Agenda of the original GM should be transacted whether there is a sufficient quorum or not.
  • What if the election is not held before expiry of the term of the MC?
    Ans. Under Section 73H of the Act, “it shall be the duty of the committee of every society to arrange for holding the election of its members before the expiry of its term. Where there is wilful failure on the part of the committee to hold the election to the committee before the expiration of its term, the committee shall cease to function on the expiration of its term and the members thereof shall cease to hold office and the Registrar may himself take over the management of the society or appoint an Administrator”.
    As such, any act of the Managing Committee subsequent to the expiration of its term will be at its own risk and consequences, and loss if any, suffered by the Society will have to be made good by the Committee Members themselves.
  • What is the procedure for expulsion of a Member?
    Ans. The expulsion of a Member is an extreme step and requires scrupulous following of the procedure prescribed. (The grounds for Expulsion of a Member is answered separately under “Section B: Members”). The procedure prescribed to expel a Member, who has brought disrepute to the Society or has done other acts detrimental to the interest or proper working of the Society, is the following:
    (1) The Managing Committee should consider the issue of expulsion (either on a written notice from a Member or on its own) in its Meeting and decide to bring such a resolution;
    (2) The consideration of such resolution should be included in the Agenda for the next General Meeting (Special or Annual) to be held not earlier than one month from the date of notice to the Member concerned;
    (3) A Notice (observing the period at (2) above) should be given to the Member concerned, calling upon him to be present at the General Meeting and to show cause against expulsion to the General Body of Members;
    (4) In the General Meeting so called, after hearing the member concerned if present, or after taking into consideration any written representation which might have sent, the General Body of Members present, by a majority of not less than three-fourths of the Members entitled to vote, pass a resolution expelling the Member concerned;
    (5) The Managing Committee should send the resolution to the Registrar for approval.
    (6) The resolution becomes effective from the date of approval by the Registrar, and the Member concerned stands expelled from that date. (Note: The Managing Committee should be cautious, and be familiar with Section 35 of the Act and Rules 28 & 29 while dealing with this issue).
  • Can an expelled Member be readmitted to the Society?
    Ans. No Member of the Society, who has been expelled from its membership, shall be eligible for readmission to membership in the society, until expiry of the period of one year from the date of his expulsion. provided that on the recommendations of the Meetings of the General Body of the Society, the expelled Member may be readmitted to its membership, as a special case before the expiry of the period of one year, with the prior permission of the Registering Authority.
  • What if the acts of MC done in good faith found to have been defective?
    Ans. According to Section 52 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860, “nothing is said to be done or believed in ‘good faith’ which is done or believed without due care and attention”. In other words ‘good faith’ = ‘due care and attention’. As such not every act of the MC, which it considers as has been done in ‘good faith’, may fit into this formula.
    However, if the MC indeed did something in good faith in pursuance of the business of the Society, which was subsequently found to be invalid or defective, the MC is protected by Section 77 of the Act. The Registrar is the competent authority to decide whether any act was done in good faith or not, and his decision is final.
  • What can be a Model Election Programme?
    Ans. The following programme may be used as a model by Societies that follow New Model Byelaws of 2001. In case of Societies following Old Model Byelaws of 1984, it may be used with suitable modifications.
    MODEL ELECTION PROGRAMME BASED ON The Maharashtra Specified Co-operative Societies Election Rules 1971
    Sr. No. Date Event/Activity
    01 15th Sep Publication of Provisional List – in the Notice Board (sixty days before the election, inviting suggestions and objections within eight days of the publication of the list).
    02 25th Sep Publication of Final List (within two days of the last date fixed for inviting suggestions and objections)
    03 05th Oct Appointment of Returning Officer (from amongst Members who should neither propose nor second any candidate).
    04 12th Oct Notice to Members inviting Nominations.
    05 20th Oct Last date for making Nominations (till 6:00 p.m., or any convenient time, but time is a must).
    06 20th Oct Publication of List of Nominations received (8:00 p.m.).
    07 21st Oct Scrutiny of Nominations
    08 22nd Oct Publication of List of Valid Nominations
    09 07th Nov Last Date for Withdrawal of Nominations (6:00 p.m.).
    10 08th Nov Publication of Final List of contesting Candidates.
    11 15th Nov Poll - 11:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. (Ballot box should be locked and sealed immediately after 3:00 p.m.).
    12 15th Nov Counting of Votes – 4:00 p.m.
    13 15th Nov Declaration of Results (immediately after counting of votes).
    Note:
    (1) Sr. No. 1 to 3 are the functions of Managing Committee, and the rest are of the Returning Officer.
    (2) If the last date in the dates specified in the above cases is a public holiday, the next succeeding working day should be fixed for the respective events.
    (3) See Election Rules for other details/requirements.

Technical Section

  • Who gives license to a Private Sugar Factory?
    Ans. As per Sugar Cane Control Order 1966, Amendment 2006, date 10.11.2012 the Commissioner of Sugar is authorized to issue aerial distance certificate. After getting the Aerial Distance Certificate, the applicant is required to obtain IEM (Industrial Entrepreneur Memorandum) from Ministry of Commerce, Government of India within 30 days time period. After that, the applicant has to deposit a Bank Guarantee of Rs. 1 Crore within 30 days time to the Chief Director of Sugar, Government of India .
  • What should be the minimum distance between two sugar factories?
    Ans. As per Sugar Cane Control Order 1966, Amendment 2006, clause 6 A, the minimum aerial distance between two sugar factories should not be less than 15 km. State Government of Maharashtra by issuing a Gazette notification dated 03.12.2011, the minimum aerial distance between two sugar factories has increased from 15 km to 25 km with prior approval of Government of India.
  • Whether private factories receive any Government fund/loans for erection?
    Ans. No. The State Government does not give any fund, financial assistant for erection of private sugar factories.
  • How much land is required for private sugar factories?
    Ans. State Government has not specified any norms regarding this. The land requirement is as per capacity of sugar factory.
  • What is the procedure to erect private sugar factories?
    Ans. As per Sugar Cane Control Order 1966, Amendment 2006, date 10.11.2006, describes the procedure for different approvals to be taken before erection of private sugar factory.

Finance Section

  • What is FRP?
    Ans. FRP stands for Fair and Remunerative Price, which is the minimum price payable to the sugarcane growers/ suppliers who have given their sugarcane for crushing to the sugar factory. FRP is declared every year, for the forthcoming sugar season, by the Central Government. For the crushing season 2011-2012, the FRP has been declared to be Rs 145 per quintal of cane for recovery of 9.5 %. And additional price of Rs 15.3 per quintal for every additional 0.1% recovery.
  • How the Final Cane Price is calculated?
    Ans. After cane payment is made as per the declared FRP and after making all provisions as per the law and directions of Mantri Samiti in the balance sheet of the ssk; if there is any surplus income leftover, then the ssk may make additional cane payment to the cane farmers. However this final cane price has to be by the prior approval of the Sugar Commissionerate. The conditions to be fulfilled for declaration of final cane price have been listed in the proceedings of the Mantri Samiti meetings.
  • What is RRC?
    Ans. RRC stands for Revenue Recovery Certificate. RRC is issued by the Commissioner of Sugar against the sugar factories who have defaulted in making cane payments within the stipulated time as per provisions of the Sugarcane Control Order. As per provisions of Section 3(8) of the Sugarcane Control Order 1966, in case of default in payment of cane price, the Central/State government shall issue a Revenue Recovery Certificate against the defaulting unit, whereby the amount of the price of Sugarcane and interest thereon may be recovered from the sugar mill, as an arrears of land revenue. So in case, any sugar mill has not made cane payment as per the declared FRP, the Sugar Commissioner may issue an RRC against it. Once the RRC is given, the Collector of the respective district is empowered to attach and sell the movable and immovable assets of the mill and use the amount realized to make payment to the cane farmers.
  • Can RRC be given for private sugar factories?
    Ans. Yes, the provisions of Section 3 (8) are applicable to private sugar mills also.
  • What is the process to be followed for issuing RRC?
    Ans. According to the Sugarcane Control Order Section 3(3), the sugar mill is bound to give cane payment to the supplier of sugarcane as per the declared FRP, within 14 days of delivery of cane to the factory. If it fails to do so the unpaid amount is treated as an arrears of cane payment. As per provisions of Section 3(8) of the Sugarcane Control Order, in case of default in payment of cane price, the Central/State government shall issue a Revenue Recovery Certificate against the defaulting unit, whereby the amount of the price of Sugarcane and interest thereon may be recovered from the sugar mill, as an arrears of land revenue.
    So, in case any sugar mill has not made cane payment as per the declared FRP, the Sugar Commissioner may issue an RRC against the mill.
    For the purpose of issuing RRC following process is to be followed –
    1)The Regional Joint Director (Sugar) shall issue notice to the defaulting sugar mill and call for hearing to ascertain the amount of sugarcane dues as per the FRP.
    2)Then the RJD shall send a detailed report regarding the sugarcane dues of the sugar mill to the Sugar Commissionerate.
    3)The Sugar Commissioner shall, on receipt of report from the RJD, issue notice to the defaulting unit, asking them to show cause for delay in cane payment.
    4)Hearing is taken in front of Sugar Commissioner for which representatives of the sugar mill, RJD, Special Auditor of the mill, etc are present.
    5)After hearing all parties, the Sugar Commissioner shall, if necessary, issue a RRC, whereby the sugarcane arrears will be treated as an arrears of land revenue and accordingly the process of recovery may be initiated.
    6)How road grants are given to sugar factories ?
    Road grants are given to sugar factories for the purpose of development and maintenance of road infrastructure within the area of operation of the sugar factory.
    According to provisions of GR of Govt.of Maharashtra, dated 4 January 1992, a sugar factory is entitled to get road grants at the rate of Rs 4 per ton of sugarcane crushed, provided that the said factory has made full payment of the sugarcane purchase tax assessed for that particular financial year. A separate budgetary provision is made every year by the State Govt for the purpose.

data.name: lbl_ISMA
data.value:
Indian Sugar Mills Association (ISMA):
The oldest industrial association in the country was established in 1932 when tariff protection was granted to the industry. It is recognized by the Central and State Governments as the central apex organization to voice the cause of the sugar industry. Sugar mills in the private sector as well as the public sector are eligible to become members of ISMA. Its total strength of membership as on date stands at 234 and accounts for about half of country’s total sugar production. ISMA’s history is synonymous to the growth of the sugar industry in India which also began in early 1930s.

data.name: lbl_miscellaneouscontent
data.value:
What is FRP? How it is calculated?

    FRP stands for Fair and Remunerative Price, which is the minimum price to be paid by the sugar mills to the cane suppliers/growers who have given their cane for crushing to the mill. Prior to 2009 the Central Government had been fixing the Statutory Minimum Price (SMP) of sugarcane, for every sugar season, as provided in Clause 3 of the Sugarcane Control Order, 1966. The following factors are taken into consideration while calculating the SMP-
  • Cost of production of sugarcane
  • Returns to the growers from alternative crops and the general trend of prices of agricultural commodities
  • Availability of sugar to consumers at fair price
  • Price at which sugarcane produced from sugarcane is sold by sugar producers
  • Recovery of sugar from sugarcane
  • The realization made from sale of by-products viz. molasses, bagasse and press mud or their imputed value

On 22nd October, 2009 the Sugarcane Control Order was amended, by inserting clause (g) which provides for giving reasonable margins to the growers of sugarcane on account of risks and profits. Powers were accordingly given to the Central Government to fix a Fair and Remunerative Price (FRP) from 2009-2010 sugar seasons, effective from 1.10.2009.
The SMP/FRP is fixed on the basis of the recommendations of the Commission for Agricultural Costs and Prices (CACP) in consultation the various State Governments and associations of sugar industry and the cane growers.
For the season 2011-2012, the Central Government has fixed the FRP of sugarcane at Rs 145 per quintal of cane, linked to a basic recovery rate of 9.5%, along with a premium of Rs 1.50 for every 0.1% point increase in the recovery. SMP/FRP of sugarcane payable by sugar factories for sugar season since 2001-2002 is as given below,
Sugar Season SMP/FRP per quintal Recovery Rate %
2001-02 62.05(SMP) 8.5
2002-03 69.50(SMP) 8.5
2003-04 73.00(SMP) 8.5
2004-05 74.50(SMP) 8.5
2005-06 79.50(SMP) 9
2006-07 80.25(SMP) 9
2007-08 81.18(SMP) 9
2008-09 81.18(SMP) 9.5
2009-10 107.76(SMP) 9.5
2009-10 129.84(FRP) 9.5
2010-11 139.12(FRP) 9.5
2011-12 145.00(FRP) 9.5
2012-13 190.00(FRP) 9.5

Aerial Distance Certificate Information

After delicensing of sugar industry, the Govt. decided that in order to avoid un healthy competition among sugar factories to procure sugarcane, a minimum distance of 15 km would continue to be observed between an existing and new sugar factories by exercise of powers under the Sugar Cane Control Order dated 10th November, 2006 and this order was made applicable from the date of its publication in the official gazetee ie w.e.f. 10th November, 2006.

Clause 6A puts restriction on setting up of two sugar factories within the radius of 15 kms. It provides that no new sugar factory shall be set up within the radius of 15 kms. of any existing sugar factory or another new sugar factory in a state or two or more states. However, the State Government have been authorized to notify minimum distance higher than 15 kms with the prior approval of the Central Government. As per explanation 3 of Clause 6A minimum distance shall be determined as measured by Survey of India.

Clause 6B prescribes the requirements for filing the Industrial Entrepreneur Memoranda (IEM). It provides that before filing the IEM with the Central Government, the concerned person shall obtain a certificate from the Cane Commissioner or Director (Sugar) of Specified Authority of the concerned State Government and after filing the IEM, the concerned person shall submit a performance guarantee of rupees One crore to Chief Director (Sugar), within thirty days of filing the IEM as a surety for implementation of the Industrial Entrepreneur Memorandum within the stipulated time or extended time as specified in Clause 6C failing which IEM shall stand de-recognized as far as provisions of this Order are concerned.

State Government, vide a publication of gazette on 03.12.2012, with prior approval of Central Government, has notified the minimum aerial distance 25 km. between two sugar factories.

data.name: lbl_Ncdc
data.value:
National Co-operative Development Corporation (NCDC):
The National Cooperative Development Corporation (NCDC) was established by an Act of Parliament in 1963 as a statutory Corporation under the Ministry of Agriculture. NCDC is endowed with in-house technical and managerial capabilities in the areas of Cooperation, Organization & Methods, Financial Management, Management Information Systems, Sugar, Oilseeds, Textiles, Fruits & Vegetables, Dairy, Poultry and Live stock, Fishery, Handlooms, Civil Engineering, Refrigeration and Preservation to help cooperatives to identify/formulate projects and successfully implement them.

data.name: lbl_NewInitiative
data.value: New Initiatives

data.name: lbl_newintitiativecontent
data.value:
Government subsidy for purchase of Cane Harvester Machine

Maharashtra accounts for one third of the total Sugar production in India. In 2010-11, the state had Sugar Cane cultivation in area of 10.22 Lakh hectares. This has increased to 10.43 Lakh hectares in the year 2011-12. Increasing area under cultivation consequently, requires larger work force for the harvesting and transportation of sugarcane.

However in recent years the sugar industry is facing a major shortage of laborers for the purpose of harvesting and transportation of cane. Due to various Government initiatives like educational facilities, alternate employment options available for workers, changes in lifestyle due to improved social & educational standard, day by day the number of laborers is decreasing in the state. As such, the Sugar factories in the state are facing a labor crunch.

To solve this problem, it is essential to use modern technology to harvest the cane crop. So the Govt. has taken the initiative to encourage the use of mechanical harvesters to harvest some area of sugar cane crop. By using the Cane Harvesting Machines the problem of labor shortage can be solved to some extent. However, due to high purchase cost of these Cane Harvester Machines, the buyers of these machines need some financial assistance from the Government. Accordingly, the Government has taken a decision to give 25% of the cost of the machine or maximum Rs. 25 Lakhs as subsidy to the purchasers i.e. the farmers or the co-operative Sugar mills.

E-Governance Initiative at Sugar Commissionerate

As part of the e-Governance initiative of Government of Maharashtra , a new state-of-the-art web portal of Sugar Commissionerate of Maharashtra has been developed by Mahaonline Ltd., under the guidance of Sugar Commissioner Shri. Vijay Singhal. It contains information about Sugar, the Sugar industry in Maharashtra, details of the Commissionerate and its various sections, details of all Cooperative & Private Sugar factories in the state including their address & Google maps of their locations. The website will also carry information related to Sugar department like important Government Resolutions (GR), Circulars, Court Orders, Guidelines etc. This information will be useful for Cane Harvesters, Sugar Factories, Departmental staff as well as industry experts, researchers & the citizens.

Work is also in progress for development of the Maharashtra Sugar Information System (MSIS) – an application for automating the governance structure of various sections in the Commissionerate & allied offices across the state. The MSIS will have users at various levels – at Mantralaya, at the Sugar Commissionerate & its Regional offices as well as the Sugar factories. Through this software, the department will be able to track various details like Sugar crushing & Production Statistics, Recovery (%) Administrative & FINANCIAL DETAILS of factories, etc. Using this applications factories will be able to submit online proposals for cane crushing license, Technical sanctions, expansion and modernization, Administrative & FINANCIAL approvals, various loans and grants proposals etc.

The department is also planning to revive the portal developed for ‘Online Sale of Sugar and by-products ’ by SSKs. The total annual turnover of Sugar & its by-products is estimated at Rs. 25,000-30000. Crores. Implementing sugar sale through Internet will help in curbing the malpractices currentaly rampant in the industry. Also, the portal will provide a National & International platform for even smaller sugar factories in the state. The online process will help in increasing the number of participants in the tendering process & will also result in increase in Tender revenue. This will help sugar factories & subequently, the farmers in getting good returns for their cane crop.

It is also proposed to create a UID Aadhar-linked database of members of all co-operative sugar factories in the state. This will enable factories to transfer the member’s cane payment directly into their Aadhar-linked bank accounts. This will result in simplified & quick processing of cane payments to the farmers.

Sugar Commissionerate is implementing a GIS solution. In first phase, all sugar factories in the state have been mapped on the states district wise map. All factory information is available at a single mouse click. In the next phase,village wise listing of factory working area is being marked on GIS maps to denote high & low recovery zones, high production capacity areas, factories showing good financial performance etc. on the map.

Formation of THINK TANK within Sugar Commissionerate

Sugar industry is one of the most important industries in Maharashtra. Maharashtra contributes nearly 35% of the total sugar production in the country. The sugar industry in Maharashtra brings in about Rs 2200crores in the form of revenue to the Central and State Govts.

However this important industry is subject, on a large scale, to the vagaries of nature. Quite often the industry is adversely affected due to uncertainty in the availability of sugarcane; which is dependent upon the climatic conditions. It is also affected by the uncertainty in the rates of sugar and its by-products which are dependent on the domestic and international market conditions.

Hence to address the problems faced by the sugar industry in the state it has been decided to form a THINK TANK within the aegis of the Sugar Commissionerate, which will not only look into the current issues related to the industry but also offer solutions with the help of experts from the related areas

The THINK TANK is also expected to study the sugar industry within and outside the country and collect information regarding the sugar production, recovery, by-product production, etc and also the innovations and success stories within the sugar industry,and, try with the help of experts to adapt them for the development of the sugar industry in the state.

The Sugar Commissioner will be the Chairperson of the THINK TANK. Members include the Directors of Sugar( Finance and Admn) in Sugar Commissionerate, Director- General of Vasantdada Sugar Institute,Pune, M.D of Maharashtra State Co-op Sugar Federation, Chairman and Managing Directors of various sugar mills (both co-op and private), Chief Chemists, Accountants of Sugar mills and other technical experts as may be required.
The THINK TANK will also look into the administrative problems faced by the sugar industry , such as timely statutory audit, cost audit, energy audit, mode of sale of sugar and by-products, procurement of raw material at remunerative prices, training of sugar industry personnel, inclusion of private mills into the mainstream, etc.
The THINK TANK will function under the guidance of Hon. Minister (Co-operation), Hon. Minister of State (Co-opertion), Hon. Secretary (Co-opertion) and Hon. Chairman, Maharashtra State Co-op Sugar Federation.

Scrutiny of Audit Reports

As per provisions of section 81 of the Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act, 1960 it is specified that statutory audit of the cooperative sugar factories is to be carried out every year. Accordingly the statutory audit is done by the Special Auditors appointed for this purpose by the Sugar Commissioners.

However it is not enough merely to carry out audit. The points/discrepancies regarding the working of the factory which are pointed out in the audit report have to be rectified also. As per provision of section 82 of the MCS Act the cooperative society has to rectify the defects and submit its Rectification Report to the Registrar within 3 months of receiving the audit report.

But it has been noticed that most of the co-operative factories neglect to do so. Consequently the defects pointed out in one audit are carried forward to the next audit report and so on. Rectification is not done on time and thus the entire purpose of carrying out audit is defeated.

Hence it has been decided that henceforth, a scrutiny of the audit reports will be carried out on a regular basis by the Regional Joint Directors (Sugar). The audit reports will be scrutinized by the auditors other than one who has done that particular audit. The purpose of this exercise will be to bring out the important defects mentioned in the audit report so that they can be caused to be rectified immediately and will not be repeated. The scrutiny will underline not only the faults but also such good points(administrative or technical), about the factory that need special mention and may serve as a pointer to other factories.

Cost Audit and Energy Audit

It has been observed that there is a lack of awareness regarding the issue of cost effectiveness of the inputs required by the sugar industry for sugar production. Hence in order to minimize the costs of the industry it has been made mandatory that a cost audit of the co-operative sugar mill shall be carried out every year. Aim is to cut down the unnecessary expenses and optimize the cost of production.

Similarly it has been made mandatory for the co-operative sugar mills to carry out energy audit every year. The sugar mills utilise fuel/energy on a large scale for their production activities. If the use of energy is optimised it will definitely be beneficial to the sugar mills. And it will also help in the conservation of energy. The energy audit will help to point out the unnecessary use of energy and it will help the sugar mill to save on the cost of fuel/energy. This will ultimately reduce expenditure and help in enhancing the financial position of the mill.

data.name: lbl_NFCSFL
data.value:
National Federation of Cooperative Sugar Factories Limited :
The National Federation of Cooperative Sugar Factories Ltd (NFCSF) was registered as a Multi-Unit Cooperative Society on December 2, 1960 under the provisions of Bombay Cooperative Societies Act 1925 as extended to the Union Territory of Delhi. In 1972, it was deemed to be under The Delhi Cooperative Societies Act 1972 and later under the Multi State Cooperative Societies Act 1984. Since, 2002, NFCSF is deemed to be under the Multi State Cooperative Societies Act, 2002. NFCSF owes its establishment to the resolution adopted at the first all India seminar on cooperative sugar factories, held in Etikoppaka, Andhra Pradesh in 1957.

data.name: lbl_OrganizationChart
lbl_PCIDetail
data.value:
India is the second largest producer of sugar country in the world. The sugar industry plays an important role in India’s economy. It is the second largest industry in the country, next to textiles and provides direct employment to more than 3.6 lakh persons. The cultivation and transportation of sugarcane to the sugar mills provides a source of income to large number of farmers, laborers, technicians, transport operators. It also supports a number of engineering industries located both in rural and urban areas.
Molasses, press mud and Bagasse are the three important by-products of the sugar industry. These by-products are potential pollutants unless disposed off properly.
  • Waste Waters of Sugar Manufacturing Process
    Indian Sugar mills generate a lot of waste water. The BOD of this combines waste water is very high. The pollution standards stipulate that BOD of waste water should be less than 30 mg/l for disposal into inland surface waters and less than 100 mg/l for disposal on land. BOD can be on a higher side, in case land application of treated waste water is envisaged as a secondary treatment system for further removal of BOD.

    The sugar mill waste water, as it leaves the premises, has a relatively clear appearance, however, after stagnating for some time, the waste water turns black and starts emitting foul odor. If discharged in water courses, its high BOD depletes dissolved oxygen in water and makes the environment unfit for fish and other aquatic life. Oil and grease in waste water hasten such mortalities. If untreated waste water is discharged on land, decaying organic solid and oil and grease present in the waste water clog the soil pores. The waste waters from some of the sections contain considerable amount of suspended solids which deposit and cause blockage in drains and ditches.
  • Air Pollutants
    Most of the sugar mills use Bagasse as a fuel in boilers. The burning of Bagasse in boilers produces particulate matter, oxides of nitrogen, carbon, sulphur and water vapor. Except for particulate matter, other emissions of Bagasse fired boilers are within the limits prescribed by the pollution control authorities. The particulate matter, usually referred to as fly ash, consists of ash, unburnt Bagasse and carbon particles. Fly ash is very light and it contains a large percentage of fines. If air pollution control equipment is not installed, fly ash will fully escape into the atmosphere through the chimney. The particulate matter coming out of the chimney will travel distances depending on particle size and atmospheric conditions. There is a reduced visibility in the areas surrounding the sugar mill. The heavier particles settle on vegetation and damage them. There are reports of dizziness and physiological effects like irritation in the eye, nose, throat and lungs, in the surrounding areas.
  • Recommendations
    During the process of sugar manufacture, condensates are available from juice heaters, multiple effect evaporates, vacuum pans etc. These condensates, if contaminated with juice, have to be disposed off as waste water. Recycling of condensates and cooling water helps in minimizing the amount of water joining the waste water stream. This also helps in conservation of water, which has become a scare resource for several sugar mills. Besides, sugar mills have to take steps to minimize the amount of pollutants joining the waste water stream.

    The sugar mill waste water contains large quantities of bio-degradable organic matter and therefore biological treatment processes are most commonly used for its treatment. Treated waste water with a BOD level of about 100 mg/l can be used for irrigation of sugar cane fields.

    Multi-cyclones, wet collectors, bag filters and electrostatic precipitators can reduce particulate matter in boiler emissions by 90% or more. These equipments can reduce the concentration of particulate matter to 450 mg/Nm3 or less.

    A number of sugar mills have already installed waste water treatment plants and air pollution control equipment.
Charter On Corporate Responsibility For Environmental Protection

DISTILLERIES:
    Existing Molasses -based Distilleries will furnish bank guarantee and Action Plan to concerned State Board to ensure compliance with any combination of the following measures; .
  • Compost making with press mud/agricultural residue/ Municipal Waste:
  • Concentration and drying/ Incineration:
  • Treatment of spentwash through biomethanation followed by two stage secondary treatment and dilution of the treated effluent with process water for irrigation as per norms prescribed by CPCB/MoEF.
  • Treatment of spentwash through bio- machination following by secondary treatment (BOD < 2500 mg/I) for controlled discharge into sea through a proper submerged marine outfall at a point permitted by SPCB/CPCB in consultation with National Institute of Oceanography (NIO), so that Dissolved Oxygen in the mixing zone does not deplete to less than 4.0 mg/I.
  • For taking decision on feasibility of one time controlled land application of treated effluent, a study will be under taken within three months.

    • The road map for utilization of spentwash by the distilleries to achieve zero discharge of spentwash in inland surface water courses will be as below:-
    50% utilization of spentwash - By March, 2004
    75% utilization of spentwash - By March,
    2005 100% utilization of spentwash - By December, 2005
    The 100% utilization of spentwash is achieved, controlled and restricted discharge of treated effluent form lined lagoons during rainy season will be allowed by SPCB/CPCB in such a way that the perceptible coloring of river water bodies does not occur.
  • Monitoring Task Force consisting of CPCB, SPCB, Experts and industry shall be constituted for monitoring the implementation of action points.
  • New Distilleries & Expansion of Existing Distilleries (Molasses-based) Proposal for Standalone new distilleries and expansion of exiting distilleries will out achieving zero discharge in surface water/ ground water will not be considered MoEF/ SPCB.
  • * To be decided by SPCB/ CPCB/ MoEF.

data.name: lbl_SugarDetail
data.value:
Steps For Sugar Manufacturing Process:


    1. Cane is weighed,unloaded into cane carriers and prepared for milling by knives and shredders.
    2. Sugarcane juice is then extracted by pressing the prepared cane through mills. Extracted juice mixed with water is sent to the boliling house for further processing .
    3. Residual bagasse is sent to boilers for use as fuel for steam genration.
    4. This juice is heated and then treated with milk of lime and sulphur dioxide.
    5. The treated juice is then further heated and sent to clarifiers for continuous setting.
    6. The clear juice is evaaported to a syrus stage ,bleached by sulphur dioxide and then sent to vacuum pans for further concentration and sugar grain formation.
    7. Crystals are developed to a desired size and then the crystallized mass is then droped in the crystallizers. This is then centrifuged for separating the crystals from molasses.
    8. The sugar crystal are dried to remove any moisture.
    9. Dried sugar is then graded in term of size.
    10. Graded sugar is then weighed,bagged and sent to storage bins.

    1.Origin of Sugar


    Sugar has been produced in the Indian subcontinent since ancient times. Originally, people chewed sugarcane raw to extract its sweetness. Sugarcane was a native of tropical South Asia and Southeast Asia. Different species likely originated in different locations with Saccharum barberi originating in India and S. edule and S. officinarum coming from New Guinea. Sugar remained relatively unimportant until the Indians discovered methods of turning sugarcane juice into granulated crystals that were easier to store and to transport. Crystallized sugar was discovered around 5th century AD.

    The five largest producers of sugar in 2010 were Brazil, India, European Union, China and Thailand. The largest exporters in 2010 were Brazil, Thailand, Australia and India; while the largest importers were EU-27, United States and Indonesia. Currently, Brazil is the highest per capita consumer of sugar, followed by Australia, Thailand and EU-27.

    2.Types of Sugar

    Granulated, white, extra fine or regular sugar is a highly refined sugar produced from sugar canes or sugar beets. It is available in cubes and tablets, with textures of various types and sizes. This is the sugar normally found in every home's sugar bowl.
    Superfine, ultrafine, or bar sugar (aka. castor or caster sugar) is a more finely granulated sugar which dissolves almost instantly. It's crystal size is the smallest of all granulated sugars, making it ideal for extra fine textured cakes, meringues and iced drinks.
    Fruit Sugar, in comparison to "regular" sugar is slightly finer and has a more uniform crystal size. Fruit Sugar is ideal for dry mixes like gelatin desserts, pudding mixes and drink mixes.
    Confectioners or powdered sugar is another granulated sugar ground to a smooth powder and then sifted. It contains a small percentage of corn starch to prevent caking, and is available in different grades of crystal fineness, the finest of which is often available in supermarkets.
    Coarse sugar has a crystal size larger than that of "regular" sugar, and is processed from sugar liquor.
    This processing method makes coarse sugar highly resistant to the natural breakdown to fructose and glucose at high temperatures, important for making fondants, confections and liquors.
    Brown sugar is a soft textured sugar made with a combination of white sugar and molasses. The two most common types of brown sugar are light and dark. The lighter the brown sugar is, the more delicate the flavor.
    2.1) Cane Sugar & Beet Sugar
    Cane sugar contains trace minerals that are different from those in beet sugar, and it’s these minerals that many experts say make cane sugar preferable to use. As professional bakers have long noticed, cane sugar has a low melting-point, absorbs fewer extraneous and undesirable odors, blends easily and is less likely to foam up. And that can be very important when you’re caramelizing syrup, making a delicate glaze, baking a delicious meringue, or simmering your family’s favorite jam recipe.

    3.Sugar Grading Information

    3.1) Requirements For Grain-Size Group Of Crystal Sugar Ref. Is 498: 2003
    SR. No Grain-Size Group Designation Retained on Percent Retained by Mass, Min.
    IS Sieve Tyler Sieve
    I) L 1.70 mm
    850 micron
    600 micron     		10

    99
    II) M 1.18 mm
    600 micron

    3.2) Requirements of Plantation white Sugar as per IS 5982: 2003
    SR. No Characteristics Requirement
    1 Loss on drying % by mass, max. 0.10
    2 Polarization, Min 99.5oZ
    3 Reducing sugar percent by mass, Max 0.10
    4 Color in ICUMSA units, Max. 150
    5 Conductivity Ash, percent by mass, Max 0.10
    6 Sulphur dioxide, mg/Kg, Max 70
    7 Lead, mg/kg, Max 5.0

    3.3) Requirement of Refined Sugar as per IS 1151:2003
    SR. No Characteristics Requirement
    1 Loss on drying % by mass, max. 0.05
    2 Polarization, Min 99.7oZ
    3 Reducing sugar percent by mass, Max 0.04
    4 Color in ICUMSA units, Max. 60
    5 Conductivity Ash, percent by mass, Max 0.04
    6 Sulphur dioxide, mg/Kg, Max 15
    7 Lead, mg/kg, Max 0.50
    8 Chromium, µg,/ kg, Max 20

    4.ICUMSA

      ICUMSA stands for International Commission for Uniform methods of Sugar Analysis, a worldwide body which brings together the activities of the National Committees for sugar analysis in more than thirty member countries. Work is carried out under various subjects, each headed by a referee. ICUMSA is the only international organization concerned solely with analytical methods for the sugar industry. In addition to use by that Industry, ICUMSA methods are recognized by authorities such as the Codex Alimentarius Commission, the OIML, the EU and the US Food Chemicals Codex. Methods are recommended for Tentative (T) approval by ICUMSA in the first instance. Upon meeting all the commission's requirements, methods are accorded Official (O) status. Methods which are demonstrably useful and have found an established application, or which do not lend themselves to collaborative testing, are given an Accepted (A) status.
      The following is the list of General Subject and the Subject:


      GENERAL SUBJECT SUBJECT
      GS1 Raw Sugar s1 Constitution and By-Laws
      GS2 White Sugar s2 Oligosaccharides and Polysaccharides
      GS3 Specialty Sugar s3 Method Format, Collaborative Testing and Statistical Treatment of data.
      GS4 Molasses s4 Density, Optical Rotation and Refractive Index
      GS5 Cane s5 Dry Substance
      GS6 Beet s6 Indirect methods of analysis
      GS7 Cane Sugar Processing s7 Color, Turbidity and Refectance Measurement
      GS8 Beet Sugar Processing S8/9 Chromatographic Techniques
      GS9 Plantation White Sugarg S10 Enzymatic and Immunological Methods
      S12 Microbiology
      S13 Reducing Sugars
      S13 Ash

    International Commission forUniform MethodofSugar Analysis (ICUMSA)

      The objectives of the Commission are:
      1) To provide an international forum for all matters pertaining to the science of sugar analysis.
      2) To promote by all appropriate means the study of matters pertaining to methods for analyzing sugars and products and axillary materials of sugar production for whichthere is a visible demand from international commerce for uniformity of analysis andto encourage scientific research relating to the analysis of sugars and sugarproducts.
      3) To provide for the interchange of information between the different countries.
      4) To agree upon and to publish international recommendations for uniform methods ofsugar analysis.

      ICUMSA White Sugar Method Includes
      i) Visual appearance
      ii) Color in solution
      iii) Polarization of white sugar
      iv) Conductivity ash
      v) Particle size distribution
      vi) Reducing sugar
      vii) Loss on drying
      viii) Sulphurdioxide
      ix) Insoluble matter
      x) Copper
      xi) Calcium
      xii) Iron
      xiii) Reflectance of Sugar

      As per the prevalent practice sugar of following ICUMSA is acceptable in the following geographies viz :
      EUROPE, USA, AUSTRALIA, NEWZELAND ---- below 45
      ICUMSA AFRICA ---- up to 100-150
      ICUMSA ASIA ---- up to 100-150
      ICUMSA In some countries very very high pol (V V H P) Raw Sugar is also consumed.

data.name: lbl_SugarDevDetail
data.value:
1. Sugar Cane Development

It is the responsibility of the sugar factory to ensure cane availability during the crushing season. The Sugar Commissionerate, M.S. guides and instructs the sugar factories in the state to implement cane development activities so that all their cane requirements are fulfilled from the shortest distance with in the area of operation.

As a part of this program the Commissioner of Sugar had issued a circular dated 3rd June 2002. The sugar units were instructed to implement the following cane development activities to achieve their targets.
A) To plan the cane area (in hectares) and bring it under recommended high yielding and high sugared varieties so that the cane requirement will be fulfilled from the zone only.
B) To implement the cane development activities so that cane productivity will be increased and farmers get more returns.
C) To increase the sugar recovery percentage from the amount of sugar cane crushed.
D) To implement development activities so that local problems like soil salinity, limited availability of irrigation water etc. will be solved.

All the sugar factories were instructed to implement the five year program with deciding targets as per local situation & resources available, implements the solutions by studying problems and implement programs including extension and development activities. Beside this the book of “ Uus Lagvadiche Tantra ” is also supplied to them . Brief information about the cane development schemes of sugar development fund cane development fund and other assistance is given here .
  • i. Sugar Development Fund (SDF)
    Government of India issued a Sugar Development Fund Act. 1982 with their notification dated 20/3/1982 for the development of sugar industry and related factors. According to the Act, the cess of Rs. 14 per quintal of sugar was charged with central excise Tax. The Government had also issued a notification dated 27.9.1983 describing the rules for waan / subsidy assistance. According to it and timely modifications the purpose of fund utilization is as below.
    Sr.No Date of Notification Purpose of Assistance
    1 27.9.1983 1 Loan for modernization / Rehabilitation of machinery of sugar factory.
    2 Loan for sugarcane development.
    3 Grant for research.
    4 Assistance for Buffer stock maintenance.
    2 21.6.2002 Transport subsidy for sugar export.
    3 19.8.2002 Loan for Rehabilitation of sugar unit.
    4 29.1.2003 1 Loan for production of Anhydrous Alcohol or Ethanol from Alcohol.
    2 Loan for Bagasse based co-generation power projects.
  • ii. Cane development fund and crop loan programs:
    The cane development fund is maintained by sugar factories by deducting Rs. 4 per metric tonnes of cane crushing while finalizing the cane payments as per decision of the Mantri Samitee. Sugar factories use this fund to implement cane development programs, irrigation development, technology enhancement & publicity activities as per guidelines and rules of fund after taking prior sanction.
    Beside this the sugar factories can obtain crop loan on sugar factory’s guarantee from nationalized / co-operative bank. They can also obtain crop loan from state / district co-operative bank to implement pilot project. They may repay the loan amount along with interest after deducting it from cane price of the crushed cane under loan development activity.

2.Sugar schemes

  • i. Grant of financial assistance to Scheduled Castes/ Neo-Buddhists for purchase of shares of co-operative sugar factories –
    Financial assistance is given by the State Govt. under this scheme to the small and marginal farmers belonging to the Scheduled Castes/ Nav Bauddhas to facilitate them to acquire share in co-operative sugar factory. 50% of the cost of share is given as interest- free loan and 50% is given as subsidy. Interested beneficiaries should apply to the concerned sugar factory and then the applications will be forwarded to the Regional Joint Directors for further action.
  • ii. Grant of financial assistance to Scheduled Tribes/ Adivasis for purchase of shares of co-operative sugar factory –
    Financial assistance is given by the State Govt. under this scheme to the small and marginal farmers belonging to the Scheduled Tribes/ Adivasis to facilitate them to acquire share in Co-operative Sugar factory. 50% of the cost of share is given as interest- free loan and 50% is given as subsidy. This scheme is implemented through the Joint Registrar (Tribal Sub-plan).
  • iii. Subsidy for the purchase of Harvester Machines –
    The sugar industry faces a major problem every year as regards availability of labor for harvesting the sugarcane. In order to solve this problem and also to ensure that the farmers` sugarcane crop is not left unharvested, the government has undertaken a major initiative to acquire the mechanical sugar harvesters. In order to encourage the use of harvesters the govt. has launched this scheme under the Rashtriya Krishi Vikas Yojana (RKVY) whereby the govt. will give 25% subsidy (up to max limit of Rs 25 lakhs) against the price of the harvester to the buyer i.e. sugar factory or farmer. Applications are to be sent to the Sugar Commissionerate through the Regional Joint Directors (Sugar).
  • iv. Financial assistance for infrastructure development to sugar factories from additional revenue collected for cane purchase tax (Road Grants)-
    Grant in aid is given to the sugar factories for the construction and maintenance of internal roads within the area of operation of the factory. The grant is given at the rate of Rs 4 per metric ton of sugarcane crushed by the factory for that particular year. Provided that the concerned sugar factory has made full payment of the Sugarcane Purchase Tax assessed for that particular year and is not in arrears.
  • v. Financial Assistance for Sugar Research to Vasantdada Sugar Institute, Pune –
    The State Govt. by way of budgetary provision gives a minimum grant of Rs 500 lakhs per year and an additional grant of Re. 1 per ton for any extra sugarcane crushed beyond 500 lakh metric tons by the mills in the state, to Vasantdada Sugar Institute, Manjri, Pune. The assistance is given mainly for carrying out research in the areas of increase in production and productivity of sugarcane, increasing recovery of sugar, expansion and modernization of sugar mills etc.
  • vi. Share Capital Contribution to Co-operative Sugar factories for Co-generation projects –
    5% of the project cost is given by the State Govt. to co-operative sugar factories which have taken up co-generation projects. This is in tune with the Government’s policy of encouraging development of non-conventional energy sources.
  • vii. Sugar Recovery loss subsidy –
    In the seasons when there is excess sugarcane in the state, the sugar factories have to be run beyond the normal period of 160 days, so that the entire crop can be crushed and the farmers do not suffer any loss. However, in such cases as the cane is crushed late in the season, the factories get low recovery of sugar. In order to make up this financial loss to the factories, the state govt. gives financial assistance in the form of recovery loss subsidy. This is a discretionary scheme, implemented only in occurrence of excess cane.
  • viii. Transport subsidy -
    Transport subsidy is given to the sugar factories in the seasons when there is excess cane in the state. In order to ensure that the cane crop is crushed and the farmers do not suffer any loss due to uncrushed cane, the state government encourages the factories to bring in cane from far flung regions also. And to compensate the extra expenses which the factories incur in transporting this cane, the government gives them financial assistance in the form of transport subsidy. This also is a discretionary scheme, implemented only in cases of excess availability of cane.
  • ix. Subsidy for uncrushed cane –
    Sometimes due to unavoidable circumstances, like unavailability of labor, rain during crushing season etc some of the sugarcane cannot be harvested and the crop has to be left standing in the fields. In such cases, to compensate the loss suffered by the farmer, the govt. gives Rs 25000/hectare as subsidy to the farmer.

data.name: lbl_Sugarsangh
data.value:
Sakhar Sangh
The sugarcane growers in the State were really encouraged by the announcement in 1954 by the then Bombay State Government of the 12 places in the State where sugar factories could be established, with an offer of Government share capital contribution of Rs.10 lacs each if Co- operative Societies are organised for the same. The announcement fetched rush of application from about 16 Co-operative Societies. A meeting of the Promoters held in the office of the Bombay State Co-operative Bank formed a Central Committee under the Chairmanship of Prof. Dhananjayrao Gadgil for guidance the Societies about the important issues like share capital, sugarcane area, irrigation, site selection, land, transport facilities etc. State Government also appointed a Cabinet Sub-Committee for Co-operative sugar factories. With the increase in number of Co-operative sugar factories and the tremendous response received from co-operators, need of apex Institutions to guide and advise the Societies was felt. Hence on 11/2/1956 Bombay State Sahakari Sakhar Karkhana Sangh was registered when 14 factories (inclusive of a Khedut Factory from Surat Dist.) were affiliated.

data.name: lbl_VAMNICOM
data.value:
VAMNICOM:
VAMNICOM is conceived as an intellectual nerve centre for the co-operative movement. It caters to management development through training, education, research and consultancy needs of various co-operative organizations, government departments and other national bodies.

data.name: lbl_VasantDada
data.value:
Vasantdada Sugar Institute (VSI)
Vasantdada Sugar Institute (VSI) established in 1975 by the sugarcane growers of the co-operative sugar factories, is the only orgainzation of its kind in the World. The institute performs under one umbrella all scientific, technical and educational functions relevant to the Sugar Industry. The institute endeavour to improve and increase the productivity in the Sugar Industry through three main channels namely - Academics, Research and Extension. VSI symbolizes a unique partnership between Sugar Industry, the Scientific Community and the Cane Growers.

Minister of Co-operation and Parliamentary Affairs, Govt.of Maharashtra

Birth Date: 21st August 1963
Qualifications: B.Com.L.L.B. (Ex Student of Shri Shivaji Preparatory Military School, Pune)

Dist. - Pune, Maharashtra.
Present Positions
  • Cabinet Minister : Minister of Co-operation and Parliamentary Affairs, Govt.of Maharashtra
  • Founder Chairman :Nira Bhima Co-operative Sugar Factory Ltd, Shivaji Nagar, Indapur, Dist.Pune
  • Chairman:Karmayogi Shankarraoji Patil Co-operative Sugar Factory Ltd., Mahatma Phule Nagar ( Beejvadi), Indapur, Dist.Pune
  • Chairman:Dudhganga Utpadak Sangh Maryadit, Indapur, Dist.Pune
Previous Positions Held:
  • Elected as Independent MLA from Indapur Constituency in 1995.
  • State Minister for Agriculture, Soil Conservation and Horticulture. Guardian Minister of Satara in 1995-1999.
  • Elected as Independent MLA for Second Term consecutively in 1999.
  • Chairman of PWD & Irrigation Standing Committee of Vidarbha in 1999.

  • Elected as Independent MLA for Third Term consecutively in 2004.
  • Cabinet Minister of Marketing, Employment Guarantee Scheme, Parliamentary Affairs, Women and Child Dev. (Supported Congress led Government) in 2004 .

  • Introduced Programs and Schemes for overall health development of Women and Children residing in Rural Areas.
  • Visited countries like United States, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, Canada, Mexico, Brazil, Israel and 35 other countries on Study Tours.
  • Established many Educational Institutes in Pune Region.
